title: Were Northern Europeans primitive before Christianity? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Before”? We stayed primitive until about 1920, for some definition of the word.. Look, it all depends on what you mean by “primitive”. We certainly imported many social advances from further south, such as the concept of a state with an administration and permanent taxation (as opposed to asking for contributions to a war). Society was always more egalitarian up here, and we didn’t have the resources to spare for a class of philosophers or even skilled artisans. But we had a fully developed tribal society, with laws, art, and poetry. We had innovators, although they tended to be more engineers than theorists (and still are, to this day). Most of what they achieved has perished; you don’t want to live in a stone house in this climate unless you have central heating, so the architecture was based on wood; without solid houses to store things in you don’t have much need for paper to write things down; archaeologists have to dig very carefully to uncover traces of what they did. Pre-Christian Scandinavians were, in many ways, similar to the various Greek societies in antiquity, except that we had engineers instead of philosophers. (Don’t forget that the Greek philosophers generally hated people who wanted to use their theories for any practical applications whatsoever.)

No not entirely true. True that Northern Europeans weren't advanced compared to their Southern counterparts but they weren't completely primitive. Leonard Stark's answer to Did North and West Europeans live in caves during the Bronze Age? I’m not trying to offend anyone, but this is something I would repeatedly hear. Leonard Stark's answer to What were the Northern Europeans doing 3,500 years ago? Parts of Northern Europe and Western Europe were conquered by the Romans which greatly advanced them.
